title: The effects of underwater pressure on the body - Neosha S Kashef

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the bodily damage caused by rapid changes in pressure, often seen in fish that are reeled up to the surface?

options.label: A
options.text: Decompression sickness

options.label: B
options.text: Barotrauma

options.label: C
options.text: Exophthalmia

options.label: D
options.text: Boyle's gas law

multiple-choice.question: According to Boyle's gas law, what happens to air-filled spaces, such as a fish's swim bladder or human lungs, as they descend deeper?

options.label: A
options.text: They expand

options.label: B
options.text: They compress

options.label: C
options.text: They remain the same

options.label: D
options.text: They disappear

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition called when a fish's stomach is pushed out of its mouth due to rapid expansion of air in its swim bladder?

options.label: A
options.text: Exophthalmia

options.label: B
options.text: Decompression sickness

options.label: C
options.text: Barotrauma

options.label: D
options.text: Corneal emphysema

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the law that states the amount of a gas that dissolves in a liquid is proportional to its partial pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: Henry's law

options.label: B
options.text: Boyle's gas law

options.label: C
options.text: Decompression sickness

options.label: D
options.text: Barotrauma

multiple-choice.question: Why do divers need to make decompression stops when ascending from a dive?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid barotrauma

options.label: B
options.text: To allow gas to diffuse back out of their tissues and to be released through their breath

options.label: C
options.text: To avoid exophthalmia

options.label: D
options.text: To avoid decompression sickness

title: What did democracy really mean in Athens? - Melissa Schwartzberg

multiple-choice.question: In ancient Athens, most offices were filled by random lottery from a pool of citizen volunteers. What was the name of this system of randomized selection?

options.label: A
options.text: Sortition

options.label: B
options.text: Election

options.label: C
options.text: Aristocracy

options.label: D
options.text: Democracy

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the name of the governing council in ancient Athens that set the agenda and evaluated proposals?

options.label: A
options.text: Boule

options.label: B
options.text: Ecclesia

options.label: C
options.text: Legislature

options.label: D
options.text: Assembly

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the principle that encouraged wide participation in ancient Athenian democracy?

options.label: A
options.text: Ho Boulomenos

options.label: B
options.text: Sortition

options.label: C
options.text: Aristocracy

options.label: D
options.text: Democracy

multiple-choice.question: In ancient Athens, which groups were denied full citizenship?

options.label: A
options.text: Women, slaves, and foreigners

options.label: B
options.text: Men, women, and children

options.label: C
options.text: Slaves and foreigners

options.label: D
options.text: Women and children

multiple-choice.question: What is one example of how the democratic principle behind sortition still survives today?

options.label: A
options.text: Elections

options.label: B
options.text: Jury selection

options.label: C
options.text: Citizens' assembly

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: Where did Earth’s water come from? - Zachary Metz

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the presence of water on Earth compared to the rest of the solar system?

options.label: A
options.text: Water is scarce on Earth and abundant in other planets.

options.label: B
options.text: Water is abundant on Earth but rare in other planets.

options.label: C
options.text: Water is present in all forms on Earth but absent in other planets.

options.label: D
options.text: Water is present in liquid form on Earth but frozen in other planets.

multiple-choice.question: What process occurred when molten rock in the Earth's core released volcanic gases to the surface?

options.label: A
options.text: Outgassing

options.label: B
options.text: Nucleosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Supernova

options.label: D
options.text: Cosmic collision

options.label: A
options.text: They contained no water.

options.label: B
options.text: Their mineral chemical composition matched rocks on Earth and samples from an asteroid that formed at the same time as our planet.

options.label: C
options.text: They were composed entirely of oxygen and hydrogen.

options.label: D
options.text: They were made of a different type of rock.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated percentage of water that covers the Earth?
What is the name of the process by which hydrogen atoms fused together to form helium in the center of stars?

options.label: A
options.text: Nucleosynthesis

options.label: B
options.text: Outgassing

options.label: C
options.text: Supernova

options.label: D
options.text: Cosmic collision

title: Can robots be creative? - Gil Weinberg

multiple-choice.question: Who is considered the world's first computer programmer and proposed that a machine can only be considered intelligent if it can create original ideas?

options.label: A
options.text: Charles Babbage

options.label: B
options.text: Ada Lovelace

options.label: C
options.text: Alan Turing

options.label: D
options.text: Steve Jobs

multiple-choice.question: What is the Lovelace Test, and what does it propose as a way to scrutinize the idea of artificial intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: A scientific test to measure the IQ of machines

options.label: B
options.text: A way to evaluate the creativity of machines by checking if they can produce an outcome that their designers cannot explain based on their original code

options.label: C
options.text: A method to determine the speed of machine learning

options.label: D
options.text: A formula to calculate the probability of a machine making a mistake

multiple-choice.question: What is one process that has led to original, valuable, and even beautiful outcomes, and how can it be used to make machines generate original and valuable artistic outcomes?

options.label: A
options.text: The process of evolution, which can be used to mimic biological evolution and create evolutionary algorithms or genetic algorithms

options.label: B
options.text: The process of machine learning, which can be used to create complex algorithms and models

options.label: C
options.text: The process of human intuition, which can be used to create original and beautiful artistic outcomes

options.label: D
options.text: The process of random number generation, which can be used to create unpredictable and original artistic outcomes

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a fitness function in an evolutionary algorithm, and how is it used to select the most similar musical phrases to a beautiful melody?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the speed of the algorithm execution

options.label: B
options.text: To compare the similarity between musical phrases and a beautiful melody

options.label: C
options.text: To apply random mutations and recombination to musical phrases

options.label: D
options.text: To select the least similar sequences to a beautiful melody

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concern of those who question whether machine-generated art can be considered truly creative?

options.label: A
options.text: That the machine lacks the ability to understand the process of creation

options.label: B
options.text: That the machine is unable to create original and beautiful outcomes

options.label: C
options.text: That the machine lacks intention and awareness of what is being created

options.label: D
options.text: That the machine is unable to make decisions on its own

title: Plato’s Allegory of the Cave - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: According to Plato's Allegory of the Cave, the prisoners are chained up in a cave, facing a wall, and are unable to turn their heads because they are forced to watch:

options.label: A
options.text: A beautiful sunset

options.label: B
options.text: A bright light

options.label: C
options.text: Shadows flitting across a stone wall

options.label: D
options.text: A clear reflection of the outside world

multiple-choice.question: In Plato's Allegory of the Cave, the prisoner who is freed and brought outside for the first time is initially disoriented by the sunlight and finds it difficult to:

options.label: A
options.text: See the shadows on the wall

options.label: B
options.text: Look at reflections in the water

options.label: C
options.text: See the objects directly

options.label: D
options.text: See the Sun

multiple-choice.question: According to Plato, the masses are too stubborn and ignorant to govern themselves, and this is the reason why he argues for rule by:

options.label: A
options.text: Democrat kings

options.label: B
options.text: Philosopher kings

options.label: C
options.text: Tyrants

options.label: D
options.text: Monarchs

options.label: A
options.text: Ideal forms

options.label: B
options.text: Real-world objects

options.label: C
options.text: Human perceptions

options.label: D
options.text: Abstract concepts

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, the Allegory of the Cave has captured imaginations for 2,400 years because it can be read in many ways, including:

options.label: A
options.text: Explaining the origin of knowledge

options.label: B
options.text: Illustrating the problem of representation

options.label: C
options.text: Explaining the nature of reality itself

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: Why it’s so hard to cure HIV/AIDS - Janet Iwasa

multiple-choice.question: In 2008, something incredible happened: a man was cured of HIV. What was significant about this cure?

options.label: A
options.text: It was the first time a cure was attempted using antiretroviral therapy.

options.label: B
options.text: It was the first time a cure was achieved without using antiretroviral therapy.

options.label: C
options.text: It was the first time a person was cured of HIV, and it remains the only such case.

options.label: D
options.text: It was the first time a cure was achieved using a combination of antiretroviral therapy and gene editing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary mode of HIV transmission?

options.label: A
options.text: Through casual contact with an infected person.

options.label: B
options.text: Through contaminated air or water.

options.label: C
options.text: Through unprotected sex or contaminated needles.

options.label: D
options.text: Through mosquito bites.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary target of HIV in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: Helper T cells that are responsible for fighting bacterial infections.

options.label: B
options.text: Helper T cells that are responsible for fighting fungal infections.

options.label: C
options.text: Helper T cells that are responsible for fighting both bacterial and fungal infections.

options.label: D
options.text: Helper T cells that are responsible for fighting viral infections.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary challenge in curing HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: The virus is too aggressive and cannot be controlled.

options.label: B
options.text: The virus hides out in healthy T cells, making it difficult to target.

options.label: C
options.text: The virus is too weak and cannot cause significant harm.

options.label: D
options.text: The virus can only be spread through casual contact.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential approaches being researched to develop a true cure for HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: Using a combination of antiretroviral therapy and gene editing to activate all cells harboring HIV genetic information.

options.label: B
options.text: Using a single antiretroviral drug to target and destroy HIV-infected cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Using a combination of antiretroviral therapy and immunotherapy to boost the immune system.

options.label: D
options.text: Using genetic tools to cut the HIV DNA out of cells' genomes altogether.

title: How does the thyroid manage your metabolism? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the thyroid gland in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate blood pressure

options.label: B
options.text: To control the body's metabolism

options.label: C
options.text: To filter waste from the blood

options.label: D
options.text: To produce antibodies for the immune system

multiple-choice.question: What are the two most important hormones produced by the thyroid gland?

options.label: A
options.text: Thyroxine and insulin

options.label: B
options.text: Thyroxine and triiodothyronine (T3 and T4)

options.label: C
options.text: Adrenaline and cortisol

options.label: D
options.text: Growth hormone and melatonin

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the pituitary gland in relation to the thyroid gland?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce hormones that slow down the thyroid's activity

options.label: B
options.text: To sense if hormone levels in the blood are too low or too high and send instructions to the thyroid

options.label: C
options.text: To stimulate the thyroid to produce more hormones

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the body's temperature

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of hyperthyroidism, a condition where the thyroid gland sends out too many hormones?

options.label: A
options.text: A slower metabolism and weight gain

options.label: B
options.text: A faster heartbeat, constant hunger, and rapid weight loss

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in body temperature and fatigue

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in blood pressure and swelling

multiple-choice.question: What is the opposite problem of hyperthyroidism, where the thyroid gland sends out too few hormones?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperthyroidism

options.label: B
options.text: Hypothyroidism

options.label: C
options.text: Thyroid cancer

options.label: D
options.text: Thyroiditis

title: The law of conservation of mass - Todd Ramsey

multiple-choice.question: According to the law of conservation of mass, what can or cannot be done in an isolated system?

options.label: A
options.text: Mass can be created, and energy can be destroyed.

options.label: B
options.text: Mass can be destroyed, and energy can be created.

options.label: C
options.text: Mass can neither be created nor destroyed, but energy can be.

options.label: D
options.text: Mass and energy can both be created and destroyed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of adding a little energy to the combination of six carbon atoms, 12 hydrogen atoms, and 18 oxygen atoms?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of only water and carbon dioxide.

options.label: B
options.text: The formation of a simple sugar, oxygen gas, and the same amount of water and carbon dioxide.

options.label: C
options.text: The formation of a complex sugar and the same amount of water and carbon dioxide.

options.label: D
options.text: The formation of a gas and the same amount of water and carbon dioxide.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the energy applied to the atoms during a chemical reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: The energy is destroyed.

options.label: B
options.text: The energy is created.

options.label: C
options.text: The energy is stored in the bonds between atoms.

options.label: D
options.text: The energy is released as heat and light.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, where did the hydrogen atoms that formed the Earth come from?

options.label: A
options.text: They were created in the Earth's core.

options.label: B
options.text: They were formed from a high-energy soup of particles in the Big Bang.

options.label: C
options.text: They were formed from a supernova explosion.

options.label: D
options.text: They were formed from the combination of other elements.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between mass and energy, as described by Einstein's famous equation?

options.label: A
options.text: Mass is equivalent to energy.

options.label: B
options.text: Mass is greater than energy.

options.label: C
options.text: Mass is less than energy.

options.label: D
options.text: Mass and energy are unrelated.

title: Did Shakespeare write his plays? - Natalya St. Clair and Aaron Williams

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what does the term "stylometry" refer to?

options.label: A
options.text: The study of Shakespeare's plays

options.label: B
options.text: The application of linguistics to investigate questions of literary authorship

options.label: C
options.text: The analysis of syntax, grammar, and semantics

options.label: D
options.text: The study of the historical context of Shakespeare's works

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the method of stylometry?

options.label: A
options.text: To examine the historical context of Shakespeare's works

options.label: B
options.text: To investigate questions of literary authorship by analyzing the characteristics of each writer's style

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the age of Shakespeare's plays

options.label: D
options.text: To analyze the syntax, grammar, and semantics of Shakespeare's language

multiple-choice.question: What is Principal Component Analysis, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A method of reducing a high-dimensional space into a simple principal component

options.label: B
options.text: A tool for clustering data points

options.label: C
options.text: A technique for analyzing the variance in Shakespeare's works

options.label: D
options.text: A method for determining the authenticity of ancient texts

multiple-choice.question: What did the results of the stylometric analysis show?

options.label: A
options.text: That Shakespeare was a pseudonym for another writer

options.label: B
options.text: That Shakespeare worked with Christopher Marlowe on "Henry VI," parts one and two

options.label: C
options.text: That the Bard is the Bard, and the pretender's works don't match up with Shakespeare's signature style

options.label: D
options.text: That the timeless poetry of Shakespeare's lines can be captured by numbers and statistics

multiple-choice.question: What can stylometric analysis be used for, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the age of Shakespeare's plays

options.label: B
options.text: To analyze the syntax, grammar, and semantics of Shakespeare's language

options.label: C
options.text: To help determine when a work was written, whether an ancient text is a forgery, or if a student has committed plagiarism

options.label: D
options.text: To examine the historical context of Shakespeare's works

title: The last banana: A thought experiment in probability - Leonardo Barichello

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what percentage of the possible combinations of rolling two dice give the victory to player two?
What is the probability of getting a one, two, three, or four on both dice when rolling two dice?
Why is it that player two has an approximately 56% chance of winning each match, despite player one having four winning numbers and player two only having two?

options.label: A
options.text: Because player two has a higher chance of rolling a five or six on both dice.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the chance of each number being the greatest is not the same.

options.label: C
options.text: Because player one has a higher chance of rolling a one, two, three, or four on both dice.

options.label: D
options.text: Because player two has a higher chance of rolling a one, two, three, or four on both dice.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the frequency of a specific outcome, like a player two win, when you repeat random events many, many, many times?

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases.

options.label: B
options.text: It stays the same.

options.label: C
options.text: It approaches its theoretical probability.

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes unpredictable.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen to the banana if you sat on that desert island playing dice forever?

options.label: A
options.text: It would be replaced by a new banana.

options.label: B
options.text: It would be eaten by player one.

options.label: C
options.text: It would be long gone.

options.label: D
options.text: It would be given to player two.

multiple-choice.question: Where is the pancreas located in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: Behind the heart

options.label: B
options.text: Behind the stomach

options.label: C
options.text: Beside the liver

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: To break down the food we eat

options.label: B
options.text: To produce insulin and glucagon hormones

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: It tells the liver to increase sugar production

options.label: B
options.text: It makes excess sugar move into cells for energy or storage

options.label: C
options.text: It breaks down fatty substances

options.label: D
options.text: It splits up proteins

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Heart failure

options.label: C
options.text: Diabetes

options.label: D
options.text: Kidney disease

multiple-choice.question: Why is the pancreas considered an "internal health coach"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it regulates body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: Because it aids digestion and controls sugar levels

options.label: C
options.text: Because it produces digestive enzymes

options.label: D

title: How one piece of legislation divided a nation - Ben Labaree, Jr.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main issue with the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854?

options.label: A
options.text: It allowed slavery in the newly admitted state of Missouri.

options.label: B
options.text: It repealed the 34-year-old Missouri Compromise and allowed slavery in new territories.

options.label: C
options.text: It divided the large chunk of incorporated land into two new organized territories, but did not address slavery.

options.label: D
options.text: It prohibited slavery in all newly admitted states.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: Whig Party

options.label: C

title: The sonic boom problem - Katerina Kaouri

multiple-choice.question: What was the significant achievement in the history of human progress that involved breaking the sound barrier?

options.label: A
options.text: The invention of the first airplane.

options.label: B
options.text: The development of the first supersonic aircraft.

options.label: C
options.text: The first person to fly faster than the speed of sound.

options.label: D
options.text: The creation of the first sonic boom.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the aircraft that first broke the sound barrier in 1947?

options.label: A
options.text: Bell X-1

options.label: B
options.text: Boeing 747

options.label: C
options.text: Lockheed SR-71

options.label: D
options.text: Concorde

multiple-choice.question: What happens when an object goes supersonic and moves faster than the sound it makes?

options.label: A
options.text: The sound waves are dispersed in all directions.

options.label: B
options.text: The sound waves are forced together, forming a Mach cone.

options.label: C
options.text: The sound waves are absorbed by the surrounding air.

options.label: D
options.text: The sound waves are cancelled out by the object's motion.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the shape that represents the variation of pressure in the air due to a supersonic aircraft flying through it?

options.label: A
options.text: Mach cone

options.label: B
options.text: N-wave

options.label: C
options.text: Sonic boom

options.label: D
options.text: Pressure signature

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the Mach cone meeting the ground, leaving a trail known as the boom carpet?

options.label: A
options.text: A single sonic boom is heard by the observer.

options.label: B
options.text: A double sonic boom is heard by the observer.

options.label: C
options.text: The sonic boom is cancelled out by the surrounding air.

options.label: D
options.text: The sonic boom is dispersed in all directions.

title: How do your kidneys work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the main role of the kidneys in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce hormones and regulate body temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: To dispose of waste products and turn them into urine.

options.label: C
options.text: To filter the blood and detect waste in the body.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: 20-25 times

options.label: C
options.text: 30-35 times

options.label: D
options.text: 40-45 times

options.label: B
options.text: Nephrons

options.label: C
options.text: Glomeruli

options.label: D
options.text: Tubules

options.label: A
options.text: It is reabsorbed into the blood stream.

options.label: B
options.text: It is released into the urine.

options.label: C
options.text: It is sent to the bladder to be removed.

options.label: D
options.text: It is stored in the kidneys.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the hormone that increases red blood cell production?

options.label: A
options.text: Erythropoietin

options.label: B
options.text: Renin

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why Shakespeare loved iambic pentameter - David T. Freeman and Gregory Taylor

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most important things in Shakespeare's language?

options.label: A
options.text: His use of metaphors.

options.label: B
options.text: His use of similes.

options.label: C
options.text: His use of stress.

options.label: D
options.text: His use of alliteration.

multiple-choice.question: What is a dactyl in a line of verse?

options.label: A
options.text: A metrical foot of two syllables with the first unstressed and the second stressed.

options.label: B
options.text: A metrical foot of three syllables with the first stressed and the second and third unstressed.

options.label: C
options.text: A metrical foot of one syllable with the first stressed.

options.label: D
options.text: A metrical foot of four syllables with the first unstressed and the second, third, and fourth stressed.

multiple-choice.question: What is iambic pentameter?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of poetic meter that consists of five trochees.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of poetic meter that consists of five iambs.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of poetic meter that consists of ten dactyls.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of poetic meter that consists of five dactyls.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Shakespeare choose iambic pentameter for certain moments in his plays?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was easy for his actors to memorize and for the audience to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was the most popular poetic meter of his time.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was naturally suited to the English language.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was the only poetic meter he knew.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the iamb in iambic pentameter?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the heartbeat of the speaker.

options.label: B
options.text: It represents the rhythm of the sea.

options.label: C
options.text: It represents the flow of a river.

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the beat of a drum.

title: Why do buildings fall in earthquakes? - Vicki V. May

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why buildings collapse during an earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: The ground beneath them shaking violently or splitting apart.

options.label: B
options.text: The earthquake itself directly causing the collapse.

options.label: C
options.text: The displacement of the foundation and lower levels, sending shock waves through the rest of the structure.

options.label: D
options.text: The building's material type and the shape of its columns.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a building's mass and its natural frequency?

options.label: A
options.text: Mass and natural frequency are directly proportional.

options.label: B
options.text: Mass and natural frequency are inversely proportional.

options.label: C
options.text: Mass and natural frequency have no relationship.

options.label: D
options.text: Mass and natural frequency are independent of each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect known as when the frequency of the earthquake's seismic waves matches the natural frequency of a building?

options.label: A
options.text: Damping

options.label: B
options.text: Resonance

options.label: C
options.text: Absorption

options.label: D
options.text: Isolation

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using base isolation in building design?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the building's stiffness and reduce its flexibility.

options.label: B
options.text: To absorb shocks and limit deformation.

options.label: C
options.text: To isolate the foundation's displacement from the rest of the building.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the building's mass and increase its flexibility.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of engineers working with geologists and seismologists to predict the frequency of earthquake motions at building sites?

options.label: A
options.text: To design buildings that are as flexible as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: To predict the exact time and location of future earthquakes.

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent resonance-induced collapses by taking into account factors such as soil type and fault type.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the building's mass and reduce its stiffness.

title: Why the Arctic is climate change's canary in the coal mine - William Chapman

multiple-choice.question: What is the Arctic often described as in terms of predicting the impact of climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: The coal mine

options.label: B
options.text: The canary in the coal mine

options.label: C
options.text: The thermometer in the coal mine

options.label: D
options.text: The barometer in the coal mine

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the Arctic warms just a little, causing some of the snow and ice to melt?

options.label: A
options.text: The increased heat absorbed by the surfaces causes more freezing.

options.label: B
options.text: The increased heat absorbed by the surfaces causes more melting.

options.label: C
options.text: The increased heat absorbed by the surfaces has no effect.

options.label: D
options.text: The increased heat absorbed by the surfaces causes the temperature to remain the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of Arctic sea ice in terms of insulation?

options.label: A
options.text: It acts as a buffer between the frigid arctic air and the relatively warmer water underneath.

options.label: B
options.text: It acts as a buffer between the relatively warmer water underneath and the frigid arctic air.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the insulation of the Arctic.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases the insulation of the Arctic.

multiple-choice.question: What type of feedback loop is melting ice that causes a release of moisture into the atmosphere, which increases the amount and thickness of clouds present?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive feedback loop

options.label: B
options.text: Negative feedback loop

options.label: C
options.text: Neutral feedback loop

options.label: D
options.text: No feedback loop

multiple-choice.question: What may be the consequence of the reduced temperature differences between the North Pole and the equator?

options.label: A
options.text: Faster jet stream winds and more linear atmospheric circulation in the middle latitudes.

options.label: B
options.text: Slower jet stream winds and less linear atmospheric circulation in the middle latitudes.

options.label: C
options.text: No change in jet stream winds and atmospheric circulation.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased temperature differences between the North Pole and the equator.

title: McDonald's Cup Sizes Around The World

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the mitochondria in a cell?

options.label: A
options.text: To synthesize proteins

options.label: B
options.text: To store genetic information

options.label: C
options.text: To generate energy for the cell

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate cell growth

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following types of rocks is formed from the cooling and solidification of magma?

options.label: A
options.text: Igneous

options.label: B
options.text: Sedimentary

options.label: C
options.text: Metamorphic

options.label: D
options.text: Foliated

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which water moves through a plant, from the roots to the leaves, and is then released into the air as water vapor?

options.label: A
options.text: Respiration

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Transpiration

options.label: D
options.text: Evaporation

multiple-choice.question: What is the scientific term for the "building blocks of matter"?

options.label: A
options.text: Molecules

options.label: B
options.text: Atoms

options.label: C
options.text: Cells

options.label: D
options.text: Tissues

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following types of energy is a form of kinetic energy that is produced by the movement of objects?

options.label: A
options.text: Potential energy

options.label: B
options.text: Kinetic energy

options.label: C
options.text: Thermal energy

options.label: D

title: The great conspiracy against Julius Caesar - Kathryn Tempest

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary concern of Roman Senator Marcus Junius Brutus in 44 BCE?

options.label: A
options.text: He wanted to seize power for himself.

options.label: B
options.text: He was concerned about the rise of Julius Caesar to power.

options.label: C
options.text: He wanted to overthrow the Roman Republic and establish a monarchy.

options.label: D
options.text: He was worried about the increasing power of the Roman Senate.

multiple-choice.question: What was the title given to Julius Caesar in 44 BCE, which granted him potentially unlimited term power?

options.label: A
options.text: Consul

options.label: B
options.text: Dictator

options.label: C
options.text: Emperor

options.label: D
options.text: King

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason behind Brutus's hesitation to conspire against Julius Caesar?

options.label: A
options.text: He was afraid of Caesar's military power.

options.label: B
options.text: He was worried about Caesar's popularity among the Roman public.

options.label: C
options.text: He felt guilty about Caesar's past kindness and treatment towards him.

options.label: D
options.text: He was concerned about the consequences of his actions.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the assassination of Julius Caesar, contrary to the expectations of the conspirators?

options.label: A
options.text: The Roman Republic was strengthened.

options.label: B
options.text: The power vacuum led to a series of civil wars.

options.label: C
options.text: The conspirators were hailed as heroes.

options.label: D
options.text: The Roman Senate was abolished.

multiple-choice.question: How did Brutus ultimately meet his end?

options.label: A
options.text: He was executed by the Roman Senate.

options.label: B
options.text: He was killed in battle during the civil wars.

options.label: C
options.text: He took his own life due to facing certain defeat.

options.label: D
options.text: He was pardoned by the new Roman Emperor.

title: How do the lungs work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of breathing in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To transport carbon dioxide to the body's cells

options.label: B
options.text: To clear the body's system of oxygen

options.label: C
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells and clear the system of carbon dioxide

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the heart rate

multiple-choice.question: What is the trigger that starts the respiratory system functioning?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain's conscious control center

options.label: B
options.text: The autonomic nervous system, the body's unconscious control center

options.label: C
options.text: The heart rate

options.label: D
options.text: The muscles around the lungs

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles in the respiratory system?

options.label: A
options.text: To compress the lungs and force the air out

options.label: B
options.text: To flatten the diaphragm and contract the intercostal muscles to create space for the lungs to expand

options.label: C
options.text: To relax the diaphragm and intercostal muscles to make the chest cavities smaller

options.label: D
options.text: To expand the lungs and take in oxygen-rich air

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the oxygen and carbon dioxide in the alveoli of the lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxygen is unloaded into the lungs and carbon dioxide is transported throughout the body

options.label: B
options.text: Oxygen crosses over to the capillaries and carbon dioxide is unloaded into the lungs

options.label: C
options.text: Oxygen is transported throughout the body and carbon dioxide is expelled through the nose and mouth

options.label: D
options.text: Oxygen is stored in the alveoli and carbon dioxide is transported to the brain

multiple-choice.question: How many times do the lungs inhale and exhale per minute?

options.label: A
options.text: 10-15 times

options.label: B
options.text: 15-25 times

options.label: C
options.text: 25-30 times

options.label: D
options.text: 30-40 times
